body: There were cardboard boxes of income tax records, mortgage papers, photographs that elicited gloomy memories and plastic cases filled with old-fashioned floppy disks -- the kind that might have been used with some of the first personal computers on the market. People scrawled resolutions, doubts or fears on slips of paper. And one man said he had
title: Goodbye to Bad Memories, or Old Electric Bills

body: AS a teenager growing up in Flatbush, Allan Pepper used to set aside his schoolbooks every evening and tune in to the radio station WINS for the alternative education offered by the legendary D.J. Alan Freed. Mad for more, the gratefully distracted student discovered a jukebox sale and rental shop on Coney Island Avenue, not far from his home, that
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Fabled Club Seeks an Encore in Brooklyn

body: THE BASICS Hipsters? Check. Michelin-starred restaurants? Got that. The only thing missing from Brooklyn, it seemed, was a trendy hotel. Then, on Nov. 3, after months of delays (while its owner awaited a certificate of occupancy), Hotel Le Bleu opened for business. It occupies an eight-story glass tower on an industrial thoroughfare between two
title: CHECK IN, CHECK OUT

body: MORE than a neighborhood, Flatbush often refers to a sprawling community in central Brooklyn comprising multiple smaller ones. ''It really seems like a catchall for anything,'' said Lenny Linsker, a real estate investor. ''If an area is not definitely a different part of Brooklyn, it's Flatbush.'' But many smaller neighborhoods traditionally under
title: LIVING IN | FLATBUSH, BROOKLYN; Note to City Dwellers: Steals Available Here

body: AS recently as 16 months ago, there were, not surprisingly, zero hotels amid the myriad auto body shops that dot Fourth Avenue and the surrounding Gowanus area. Now there are three, and plans for a fourth, an 18,000-square-foot structure at President Street and Third Avenue. If built, the new hotel will join a Holiday Inn Express that opened on
title: Heard Near the Gowanus: Calls for Room Service

body: WHEN he was 20, Arturo Vidals told his father there were no good job opportunities in his hometown, Puebla, Mexico. ''If you're an eagle, then fly,'' his father replied. Mr. Vidals took a bus to Tijuana and hired a drunken coyote, Mexican slang for a smuggler, to sneak him across the border at San Diego. From there he rode to Los Angeles in the
title: HABITATS; Serendipity Transcends All Barriers

body: TO the sartorially challenged, the closet usually appears half-empty. When you're dressing for Stacy London, who mends errant wardrobes on TLC's ''What Not to Wear'' with all the tenderness of a darning needle, your closet might as well be bare. But on a nippy Saturday night, Ms. London's fashion-dominatrix identity had been put into storage,
title: A NIGHT OUT WITH; Dressed to Sip

body: SOME of the chickens were down by the gully and a couple had gone off into the trees, but most of the ''escaped'' hens were parading around outside the enclosure where their sisters were confined, trying to figure out how they could get back in, if they wanted to. Josh Morgenthau, keeper of the birds, was mumbling something about re-electrifying
title: City Lawyer, Country Chickens

body: Bradford Winters, a screenwriter who lives and works in New York, came home very animated after walking the picket line last Monday, the first day of the Writers Guild of America's strike against the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers. ''It was actually pretty upbeat,'' he said as he sat in his third floor walk-up in Brooklyn.
title: THE MEDIA EQUATION; Living Paycheck to Paycheck Was Already a Way of Life

body: NEW PLACES Black Mountain Wine House 415 Union Street (Hoyt Street) Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, (718) 395-2614. title: Dining Briefs

body: AT 10:45 p.m. on Saturday, Justin Olsen stood behind the bar at the Gowanus Yacht Club, a seasonal outdoor beer garden on Smith Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and made an announcement. ''The last keg of the year has been tapped,'' he said. And with that, the countdown began to the finale of one of the last remnants of summer in New York --
title: INK; A Switch From Beer to Holiday Cheer

body: A Place to Find That Elusive Book To the Editor: Re ''The Book Angels'' (Oct. 28): I was glad to read about Catherine Bohne and the rescue of her Community Bookstore in Park Slope. That store has rescued me many times when other bookstores wouldn't or couldn't take the time to help me search for a title. Once I needed a book but only knew the
title: THE CITY; Letters to the Editor

body: City Councilman Bill de Blasio, who lost a bid last year for Council speaker, said yesterday that he would run for Brooklyn borough president in 2009. Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, becomes the second candidate to officially enter the race, joining Councilman Charles Barron, who announced his candidacy in May. Marty Markowitz, who has been the borough
title: Councilman Joins Race For Top Seat In Brooklyn

body: Nick Monte, a lover of the ocean who transformed Gurney's Inn from a modest summer hotel on the beach in Montauk, N.Y., into a celebrated year-round resort offering amenities like Roman baths with heated seawater and seaweed body wraps, died on Oct. 13 in Henderson, Nev., where he had lived for the last six years. He was 90. The cause was heart
title: Nick Monte, 90; Revamped Beach Resort

body: REAL ESTATE listings are filled with houses and apartments with sky-high prices. But sometimes, a listing will turn up that seems too good to be true. Usually there's a catch, and the catch is often that the property comes with one or more rent-regulated tenants. While these houses and apartments can sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars less
title: The Price Includes Tenants

body: Pine Island, N.Y. THROUGH an odd twist of geological fate, some of North America's most fertile soil lies an hour's drive from Manhattan pavement, in the 22 square miles of Orange County, N.Y., known as the ''Black Dirt'' region. So what do farmers grow in this miracle earth? For about a century, the area has been known for onions, producing some
title: From New York's Black Dirt, A Glacial Secret Told by Onions

body: Amanda Moffat makes elaborately patterned ceramic pieces that bear some resemblance to 15th-century Italian designs but are actually inspired, she said, by more quotidian and contemporary sources like wrought iron, the heel of a good shoe or the Brooklyn Bridge. ''All that information comes out in what I make,'' Ms. Moffat said, ''and you can put
title: CERAMICS; In a Brooklyn Studio, Inspiration in a Shoe

title: Jazz Listings

body: A brief report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday, about the opening of Black Mountain Wine House in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, misstated its payment policy. The restaurant, at 415 Union Street (Hoyt Street) accepts Visa, MasterCard and American Express; it does not take cash only.
title: Correction: Dining

body: THE national median home price right now is $224,500. But finding anything even close to that in New York -- where the average sale price for a Manhattan apartment hovers just above $1.3 million -- would be like snagging a seat on a downtown No. 6 train at the height of rush hour. Or would it? In the current market, staying in Manhattan for
title: Even in New York, Affordable Apartments

body: IT wasn't supposed to matter to Brooklyn. Heath Ledger, the crown prince of the borough's celebrity aristocracy, apparently fled his fiefdom in Boerum Hill for Manhattan after splitting up with his girlfriend, the actress Michelle Williams. ''To each his own,'' said Jay Wilkinson, 29, an actor who lives in the neighborhood, speaking just blocks
title: Brooklyn's Fragile Ego-System

Tomorrow she will start doing her inventive Puerto Rican cooking here, dishes like peekytoe crabmeat and avocado terrine with Key lime mayonnaise; black grouper with sour
title: Off the Menu

body: Two years ago Freddy Saint-Aignan and his wife, Angelika, found the perfect location for their fledgling bar/restaurant, the Sugar Lounge: Columbia Street in Brooklyn. The building was just the right size, had a spacious backyard garden and sat beside Upper New York Bay. The city had big plans for the area: green space and parks, cruise ship piers
title: COLUMBIA STREET JOURNAL; Two Years Later, a Street Still Waits For Its Promised Gentrification

body: Nearly all the 65 dual-language programs in the New York City public schools are conducted in Spanish and Chinese, languages that are considered practical tools for future success. So far, French has not fit into that equation. But next month, the first French-English dual-language programs will begin at three schools in the city: Public School 125
title: French Gains Foothold on Dual-Language Map

body: IF two can live more cheaply than one, then three can live more cheaply than two. Or at least more grandly. title: THE HUNT; Companionship, and a Good Deal

title: New York Up Close; Godfathers, Glocks (Did We Mention the Bustier?)

title: Not the Hamptons. Yet.

body: LAST week on Smith Street, near the Bergen Street subway station in Brooklyn, a team of sharp-looking designers sanded away the last remaining evidence of a ragtag bar called Vegas that once occupied the site. title: Smith Street Confronts The Corporate Takeover

title: OFF THE MENU

body: Anyone who has stood for very long in the F subway station at Carroll Street, or Smith and Ninth Streets, or Church Avenue, has noticed them: the little-used express tracks through the stations that have lain dormant since the 1970s. title: CARROLL GARDENS; Mud on the Tracks

body: WHEN people ask where I live, I tailor my answer to my audience. If someone with children is asking, I'll answer, ''Park Slope,'' as if I had just won the lottery. If I'm talking to a childless friend who lives somewhere gritty -- say, Bushwick -- I'll duck the question, or mumble that I live near Prospect Park. Lovers and haters of Park Slope are
title: The Park Slope Parent Trap

title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: OUTDOOR BARS; Summer, and Drinking Is Breezy

title: URBAN STUDIES | UNWINDING; School's Nearly Out, and Mr. Chips Is Thirsty

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; The Union Street Hall of Fame

title: STREET LEVEL | Carroll Gardens; Twilight of the Trainspotters?

body: When their property tax bills start arriving this week, New Yorkers may be expecting to benefit from a 7 percent tax rate cut for the city's homeowners. title: Some May See City's Tax Cut As Anything But

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE; Does the 'G' Stand for Ghost?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; For a Gussied-Up Street, A Song of Simpler Days

body: OPENING SOON MONKEY BAR -- The changes in the lounge of this venerable bar and restaurant in the Élysée Hotel are subtle: The monkey murals have been cleaned, the stuffed-olive barstools are gone and there's a new snack menu from 5 p.m. on. But the dining room, which will open on Monday, has been completely redone. Gone is the plush 1930s retro
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: The Brooklyn borough president yesterday defended his removal of nine members from a community board that had criticized Atlantic Yards, the $4 billion high-rise-cum-arena project that he has called the future of the borough. ''Being a member of the community board is a very prestigious job,'' said the president, Marty Markowitz. ''However, it is
title: Shake-Up of Board Is Defended

body: GARDENING in New York City can require the determination of a weed pushing through a sidewalk. There are hardships of space, light, microclimate and wind, not to mention the pain of hauling supplies across town and, frequently, up several flights of stairs. Add to that the shortage of serious garden centers -- the kind with space for 50-pound bags
title: New York's Nurseries Try a Transplant

body: The letter arrived in Marilyn Oliva's mailbox yesterday from the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz. It thanked her for her dedication to the community as a member of Community Board 6, but informed her that her services were no longer needed. Ms. Oliva was disappointed. She was also not alone. title: Project's Foes Shown Door In Brooklyn

body: Officially speaking, same-sex couples who live in New York State cannot be married. Nancy Goldstein and Joan Hilty, a Brooklyn couple who celebrated their third wedding anniversary on Saturday, are an unusual exception. The two women have a pleasant Park Slope apartment, an excitable dog named Juno and a marriage certificate signed by the town
title: Legal Status Brings Security To Some Same-Sex Marriages

body: The familiar jingle of Mister Softee is a bit less ubiquitous on city streets these days, and not just because soggy weather gave the company its slowest April in history. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK SUMMER; Jangled by a Jingle, He Writes His Own

body: ALTHOUGH Beau Frank had rented for seven years in Manhattan, he had never been to another borough, except to pass through. title: THE HUNT; Finding the Right Balance

body: DEAR DIARY: It was a Friday afternoon and I was at Pennsylvania Station trying to get home to Long Island. title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: IF there is a song of the lazy, unmarried man in New York, the words and music can be found most often in that pile of yellowed and stained takeout menus on top of his fridge. title: URBAN TACTICS; In Praise of General Tso

body: There is no better day to visit your neighborhood comic store than tomorrow: Free Comic Book Day, the annual industry promotion in which participating retailers nationwide will give away titles ranging from ''Little Archie'' and ''The Amazing Spider-Man'' to ''The Lone Ranger'' and ''Transformers,'' a spectrum as wide as the stores that sell them.
title: Superhero Worship, Gotham to Riverdale

body: A 44-year-old man who investigators say assaulted two elderly women during muggings -- one of which was caught on video -- was charged in those cases and in two other crimes, the authorities said yesterday. The suspect, Jack Rhodes, was charged with two counts of robbery as a hate crime, according to the Queens district attorney's office, because
title: Man Is Charged With Hate Crimes in Attacks on 2 Elderly Women

title: For the Curious, It's Open House Season

title: LIVING IN/Downtown Brooklyn; Now Open for Living, as Well as Business

title: A Restaurateur and a Chef Part Ways, and Their Dispute Is Heading Toward Criminal Court

body: TEN years ago, the idea of worrying about the future of the land around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn would have seemed a little strange, especially in hot weather. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; Fume-Free (for Now) And Looking to the Future

author: Andrew Rice, a writer living in Brooklyn, has covered New York real estate. He is now writing a book about Uganda.
body: Mario Procida -- son of a construction boss, grandson of an immigrant stonemason -- was stalking his natural habitat, a building site. title: Betting On Star Power

body: RED HOOK, a nub of a Brooklyn peninsula jutting into the Buttermilk Channel opposite Governors Island, is perhaps not everyone's ideal place to live. A high-crime area not very long ago, it is at times eerily silent, at others mournfully full of the noise of industry. Broken glass and cracked sidewalks can still be found; amenities, while on the
title: LIVING IN/Red Hook, Brooklyn; Where Tugboats Chug and Ikea's Coming

body: To the Editor: Re ''Escape From New York,'' by Abigail A. Frankfurt (New York Observed, Feb. 25): With the sale of Stuyvesant Town, the possible sale of Starrett City and the looming Atlantic Yards development, why should we be so concerned with a struggling writer who can no longer afford her hip studio apartment? What about middle-class families
title: Priced Out, Leaving Town

body: Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, the owners of Frankies 457 Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, right, and Frankies Spuntino on the Lower East Side, went shopping for oil last year -- in Sicily. After tasting many varieties, they found a small family producer that could supply enough mellow oil from organic nocellara del Belice olives for
title: FOOD STUFF; Back From Sicily, Bearing Olive Oil

body: Since the new year began, a burst of activity has broken out in Manhattan and several Brooklyn neighborhoods as New Yorkers frenetically hunt for co-ops, condominiums and town houses, sending prices higher despite sluggish sales in many other cities. Preliminary indications from real estate firms showed that this increased activity, with open
title: HOUSING MARKET HEATS UP IN CITY

body: To the Editor: I read with interest your Feb. 11 article ''Hard Times Fall on an Ill-Loved Hero,'' about the statue ''Civic Virtue'' at Borough Hall in Kew Gardens, Queens. I work Kew Gardens, seeing the decrepit statue when I step off the subway each day, and have written letters in the past to Borough President Helen Marshall, as well as other
title: A Statue in Queens, Noted for Neglect

body: News flash: after decades as a musical bedroom community, Brooklyn now has lots and lots of clubs and performance spaces, many having sprouted in only the last few years. This weekend and next, 14 of them are presenting some of their best homegrown acts for ''Brooklyn Next,'' a festival organized by the Brooklyn Academy of Music to promote Kings
title: The Listings: Feb. 16 - Feb. 22; 'BROOKLYN NEXT'

body: OPEN NOW FLOATING MARKET ROOM AT HURAPAN KITCHEN -- This Thai restaurant, which just got a liquor license, has opened a downstairs lounge, where cocktails like the Chiang Mai Fizz (Champagne and pomegranate juice) are served along with small plates inspired by Bangkok's floating market: 29 Seventh Avenue South (Morton Street), (212) 727-2678.
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: CHEFS ON THE MOVE BILL YOSSES, who worked at Bouley and the Citarella stores, is the new pastry chef for the White House, replacing Thaddeus R. DuBois. CHRISTOPHE BELLANCA, below, who went to L'Orangerie in Hollywood in 2004 from Pic, a Michelin two-star restaurant in Valence, France, has now settled into his new job as executive chef at Le Cirque.
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: Theater Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. Previews and Openings 'ADRIFT IN MACAO' In previews; opens on Feb 13. title: The Listings: Jan. 26-Feb. 1

body: Never has listening to the Ninth Symphony of Beethoven required so much attention. Leif Inge, a Norwegian who calls himself an ''idea-based artist,'' has digitally elongated the work to last 24 hours. One hour of his recording equals about three minutes of an actual performance. Because the pitches and timbres of the instruments do not change, the
title: Around The Clock, Beethoven Stretched

body: THE lights went up too early, the cramped theater was swelteringly hot and Mike Daisey, looking a bit nervous alone onstage, could see himself sweating profusely in the mirror on the wall behind the audience. It was going to be one of those shows. ''Camus once said that the only real philosophical question is whether or not to kill yourself,'' he
title: THEATER; The Need To Think Onstage Is Driving Mr. Daisey

body: BE it belly or chop, from Niman Ranch or Meadowbrook Farms, as an accessory to seafood or a wellspring of salumi, pork has been staking such a piggy claim to prominence of late that its appearance in a cocktail feels less shocking than inevitable. What took the little oinker so long? To be accurate, pork isn't really in, but rather around, the
title: RESTAURANTS; An Italian Spot, Larded With Drive

body: PEOPLE interested in buying brownstones or town houses should not assume that all of the bargains are gone. Brokers say there are still properties in New York City that cost less than $1 million, but only if buyers are willing to venture into often overlooked neighborhoods and tolerate extensive renovations. ''You can still get a lovely brownstone
title: Finding a Town House for Under a Million

body: Gerard Jacques Beekman and Michael Sean Kaminsky celebrated their partnership yesterday at their apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Friends and family spoke about Mr. Beekman and Mr. Kaminsky and toasted them. Mr. Beekman (above, left) is 31. He is an architectural designer and a project manager at Ferguson & Shamamian Architects in Manhattan.
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Gerard Beekman, Michael Kaminsky

body: LOOKING AHEAD TASCA -- The Gaudí-esque tiles on the floor and the bar of this spot, which is to open next week, telegraph the menu of tapas and Spanish wines. The owners, Rob Meller and Craig Wilson, the chef, have even placed barrels on the bar to dispense sangria. Next door, they are building an addition, Central Kitchen, with a raw bar and
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: Sit in with a seventh-grade science class at Seth Low, a cavernous Brooklyn middle school, as paper balls fly and pens are flicked from desk to desk. A girl is caught with a note and quickly tears it up, blushing, as her classmates chant, ''Read it!'' The teacher, Laura Lowrie, tries to demonstrate simple machines by pulling from a box a hammer, a
title: Trying to Find Solutions in Chaotic Middle Schools
